awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research:  A Dynamic Unified Framework for Hurricane Storm Surge Analysis and Prediction Spanning across the Coastal Floodplain and Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Storm-driven coastal flooding is influenced by many physical processes including riverine discharges, regional rainfall, wind, atmospheric pressure, wave-induced set up, wave runup, tides, and fluctuating baseline ocean water levels. Operational storm surge models such as those used by NOAA's Ocean Prediction Center (Extratropical Surge and Tide Operational Forecast System) incorporate a variety of these processes including riverine discharges, atmospheric winds and pressure, waves, and tides. However, coastal surge models do not typically incorporate the impact of rainfall across the coastal floodplain nor fluctuations in background water levels due to the oceanic density structure. Nonetheless, the floodplain hydrology and ocean baseline water levels provide vital controls in riverine and estuarine environments (e.g., the dramatic effect seen in the Houston metropolitan region during Hurricane Harvey in 2017 and in North Carolina during Hurricane Florence in 2018). 

Recent events have shown that a unified approach that incorporates all the relevant physical processes is critical for accurate predictive simulations of coastal flooding due to extreme events. This project will tackle this challenge by melding hydrology, hydraulics, and waves into a dynamic unified computational framework that uses unstructured meshes spanning from the deep ocean to upland areas and across the coastal floodplain. Improved capacity for flood risk managers, the insurance industry, and city planners to evaluate flood risk across the entire coastal floodplain. Improved models will lead to better guidance on development and construction practices, will help make cities more resilient and will reduce risk for coastal populations and infrastructure. In addition, this work will improve coastal flood forecasting enabling federal, state, and local disaster managers, to optimize issuing warnings for evacuation and emergency planning. The collaboration between the ocean circulation, coastal hydrodynamics, and hydrology modeling communities fostered by this project will help support ambitious projects such as NOAA's National Water Center's National Integrated Water Model, which is at the preliminary stages of integration of hydrology and coastal hydrodynamics. Training of students at the intersection of hydrology, coastal hydrodynamics, physical oceanography, and computational mathematics, to help develop and apply ever-more complex and advanced models in academia, government and industry.

The proposed unified framework will improve the predicted water level gradient and flows throughout the coastal floodplain by integrally considering the rainfall-driven hydrology within the coastal floodplain as well as improving the background open ocean water level. Well-developed but coarse global ocean models will be heterogeneously coupled to high-resolution 2D shallow water equation models in order to account for large-scale baroclinic ocean processes that impact coastal water levels. Interface strategies and conditions between heterogeneous physics will be developed that allow the interfaces to move in time and space for the range of physics from dry to surface runoff to pressurized flow. Applying the right physics and associated mathematical models as the storms evolve will result in more robust and accurate models, as well as much more efficient models. This will dynamically account for the hydrologic - hydrodynamic interaction of water across the floodplain. Dynamic load balancing will account for widely varying computational (CPU) costs for each set of physics and the dynamic migration of the physics will be implemented within the heterogeneous parallel computing environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The hydrodynamics of the coastal ocean quantifies water elevation and currents in the open ocean, through estuaries, bays and  dendritic channel systems that penetrate the coastal floodplain and at times across overland regions when waters rise above flood stage. Applications include safe navigation, forecasting flood levels, water quality, coastal erosion, deposition and subsidence, and marine habitat.  There are a multitude of drivers that force these systems including tides (lunar/solar gravitational pull), the Earth's climate driven thermohaline engine (encompassing current systems such as the Gulf Stream and Kuroshio), storm surges (driven by winds and atmospheric pressure), wind waves (driven by winds) and rainfall and its resulting runoff which drains across the coastal floodplain into the system of dendritic channels and into the open ocean). While these processes occur simultaneously, they have historically been mathematically described and solved separately without accounting for their interaction. Nonetheless all these processes do interact and in order to accurately model them we need to consider them simultaneously. The focus and outcome of this work has been to integrate the various process models into a unified system in order to much more accurately compute water levels. In addition to considering the forcing processes we must ensure that dissipation processes in both the ocean and across the floodplain are accurately simulated, that all the component processes are sufficiently resolved in the computational meshes (the mesh delineates where properties of the physical system as well as elevations and current components are quantified at points or cells in space and time), and that the algorithms/code applied to form the discrete analog of the governing partial differential equations are both efficient and accurate.   

We have now incorporated all processes that drive total water levels into ADCIRC, our coastal ocean model, in more efficient and accurate ways. Tides are now forced using the direct total gravitational pull from the Sun and Moon and are locally frictionally dissipated at the bottom of the ocean and where tidal flows cross underwater mountains that penetrate the thermocline. The latter process is called directional "internal tide" generation/dissipation for which we have developed a novel  and very accurate formulation. Atmospheric forcing includes NOAA's GFS-FV3 and CFSv2 winds and atmospheric pressure fields. In addition the CICE model provides ice coverage, controlling both air-ice-sea momentum transfer and wind wave propagation/dissipation. Downscaled temperature and salinity fields from the Navy's HYCOM global circulation model GOFS3.1 are used to compute a density difference forcing term over the water column that drives the Earth's thermohaline circulation with vital features such as the Gulf Stream pulling on the order of a meter of water away from the U.S. East Coast. Coupling to the National Water Model drives hydrology in rivers and rainfall/runoff across the floodplain allowing a dynamic connection between upland hydrology and the ocean. Finally coupling to the SWAN wind wave model allows for wave breaking to drive wave induced coastal set up.

All this physics that we have integrated into one system demands that both the physical system, i.e. geometry, bathymetry/topography, and the processes be well resolved with the model mesh. We have built on and refined a model domain that covers the entire global ocean, eliminating open ocean boundaries associated with regional models, improving accuracy and robustness. We have worked to refine global meshes concentrating resolution in the shallow coastal regions and especially in select regions which concentrate bottom friction based tidal energy dissipation as well as across the mid ocean mountain ridges where internal tide dissipation is focused (Figures 1, 2, 3).  Along U.S. shores we refine coastal floodplain resolution down to 80m to 120m delineating coastal features such as inlets and inland channel systems (Figure 4). This model/mesh has become our virtual laboratory for advancing the accuracy and efficiency of coastal hydrodynamics. 

Efficiency features accomplished include the design of the thermohaline coupling. By using the Navy's GOFS3.1 model to compute ocean temperature and salinity and to then drive ADCIRC's thermohaline forcing terms, we do not have to ourselves implement a three dimensional model, dramatically reducing runtime costs yet allowing us to represent vital thermohaline effects such as those induced by the Gulf Stream. Using direct lunar/solar tidal forcing reduces run time costs due to fewer computations and improved compute core cache memory utilization. In addition, we have developed the capability to use Adaptive MPI which allows us to more efficiently distribute compute load across the compute cores we use in parallel computations. We also have improved reader core performance as we found that with ever larger input data sets were taking an increasingly larger proportion of the total wall clock time. The resulting model is both very efficient and accurate (Figures 5, 6). In fact tides are more accurate than any published global non-data assimilative model.
